Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Jo drive up to the Constable's Gateway entrance to Dover Castle, currently masquerading as HM Prison Stangmoor, and parks on the drawbridge.

Dialogue.Line: It looks like Dracula's castle.
Well, you're right about the castle bit. It used to be a fortress in the Middle Ages.
Doctor? You'll need this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo gives him an ID pass.

Dialogue.Line: Thanks, Jo.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor rings the entrance bell.

Dialogue.Line: Smile, Jo.
What?
You're on camera.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor waves at the CCTV, and the personnel in the security room stare at the crazy man on the monitor. A prison officer comes out.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, good morning. Er, observers from UNIT. My admission pass.
(into R/T) Right. Passes checked and satisfactory. Right, open the gates.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor gets back into Bessie.

Dialogue.Line: Abandon hope all ye who enter here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They drive through the gates into a courtyard.
The prisoners are restless, and making lots of noise in their cells which masks some dialogue. A central staircase leads up to a catwalk. By a glass brick wall is a door labelled Process Theatre.

Dialogue.Line: Green! Calm the men down. The Governor's on his way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Green goes up the stairs.

Dialogue.Line: Morning, Chief. Everything all right?
Will be, sir.
Good, good. Well, let's see to it.
Keep that noise down!

Dialogue.Character: (The Governor, Powers, Kettering and Summers, in a white lab coat, go up the stairs and are let through a gate to another corridor leading to steps downwards.) KETTERING
Dialogue.Line: Why do they always have to make that stupid row? SUMMERS: It always happens when sentences are being carried out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two guards are with the prisoner, who leaps up when the party enters.

Dialogue.Line: George Patrick Barnham.
No, you're not going to take me anywhere!
You have been sentenced by a court of law.
Get away from me!
The time has come for that sentence to be carried out.
Go on! Get out! All of you!
I'll give him something to calm him.
You won't give me nothing, mate. Get out, all of you!
Pack it in, Barnham. You're just being stupid.
You're not going to get me out there!
Get him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The two guards grab Barnham.

Dialogue.Line: All right.
You come easy.
Take it easy, you'll break me arm.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Protesting loudly, Barnham is manhandled up the short staircase.
It is not just Jo and the Doctor who are gathered to observe something. There is a whole gaggle of men with clipboards sitting around.

Dialogue.Line: Sorry about the noise, ladies and gentlemen. Just a temporary disturbance.
Temporary disturbance? It sounds like a full-scale riot.
Morbid lot of sensation seekers.
Then why did you insist on coming here?
Scientific curiosity, my dear.
Oh, yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Everyone sits down.

Dialogue.Line: Something's been worrying me about this Keller process ever since I first heard of it. Ah, the curtain is about to go up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Governor, Kettering and Powers enter.

Dialogue.Line: Keep them quiet.
All right, chief.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Green leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning.
Good morning.
May I introduce Professor Kettering, who will explain the process you're about to see demonstrated.
Well, as you're no doubt aware, we no longer execute our hardened criminals and killers. Modern society has progressed far beyond that primitive form of retribution. Today, science
(sotto) It all depends what you mean by progress, doesn't it.
Science has abolished the hangman's noose and substituted this infallible method. Professor Emil Keller
(sotto) People who talk about infallibility are usually on very shaky ground, I think.

For the benefit of the less sophisticated members of my audience, I will explain in very simple terms. Professor Emil Keller, the inventor of this process, discovered that anti-social behaviour was governed by certain negative or evil impulses. Now this machine, the Keller machine, extracts these impulses and leaves a rational, well-balanced individual.
It doesn't.
What?
May I be permitted to continue?
Oh, yes. Yes, please do.

Thank you. The condemned man is placed here (in a chair) after being tranquillised, with his head under this dome. A series of probes are attached to his skull so as to connect with the neural circuits. The extraction process is controlled here. The negative impulses are stored in that reservoir box there.
Where do they go after that?
Nowhere, sir. I repeat, they are stored in the box.
Which is now full of these negative or evil impulses.

Not full. The indicator registers only sixty five percent at this time. The machine has been used very successfully in Switzerland. A hundred and twelve cases have been processed to date and today we shall witness the one hundred and thirteenth. Thank you, Doctor Summers.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barnham is wheeled in on a gurney, drugged and in an operating gown.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, old chap. Up you get.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barnham is helped into the chair and a metal cap fastened to his head.

Dialogue.Line: When the process is completed, the negative impulses that made this man a criminal will have been removed. He will take his place as a useful, if lowly, member of society. Are you ready, Doctor Summers?
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kettering adjusts the machine that holds the reservoir box then goes to the main control panel and flicks switches. He nods to the Governor.

Dialogue.Line: Let the sentence of the Court been carried out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The lights go down, leaving Barnham in a spotlight. The machine starts pulsing. Barnham screams.

Dialogue.Line: I knew there was something evil about that machine.
Kettering! Look at the dial.
What of it?
It's never registered so high before.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Summers checks Barnham for a heart beat.

Dialogue.Line: Mister Kettering, what's happening?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kettering turns off the machine and the lights come back up.

Dialogue.Line: Well?
A minor malfunction. The machine compensated. The process is completed satisfactorily.
(sotto) Satisfactorily be blowed.
The subject will be taken away to recuperate and within an hour or two he will be perfectly normal.
I admire your confidence, sir.
Thank you. That is all, gentlemen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As the observers leave, the Doctor goes over to the Governor and Kettering.

Dialogue.Line: I take it everything was all right, Mister Kettering?
Yes, of course, Governor.
Then would you kindly explain, sir, that unfortunate man's reaction?
An excess of negative particles. The machine overreacted.
In other words, you don't know.
May I ask who you are, sir?
The Doctor is Scientific Advisor to UNIT, Mister Kettering.
UNIT?
United Nations Intelligence Taskforce.
How interesting, though I fail to see what concern it is
UNIT, sir, was set up to deal with new and unusual menaces to mankind. And in my view, this machine of yours is just that. Jo.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barnham is alive but unconscious.

Dialogue.Line: Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kettering enters.

Dialogue.Line: Well?
Nothing much wrong physically. Respiration normal, pulse rate's a little high but that's usual after the process.
Ah, exactly. A completely successful treatment.
The reaction was unusually violent.
Really, my dear Summers, you're as bad as that interfering fool from UNIT.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A telephone rings.

Dialogue.Line: Excuse me.
Medical wing. Yes? What? Have you told the Governor? I'll be right over.
(to orderly) Come with me. (to another) You stay with the patient.
Anything the matter?
There's been some kind of an accident in the process room. They think the man's dead.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A young man is lying on the floor. Green checks his wallet as Summers and the orderlies enter.

Dialogue.Line: What happened?
I don't know, sir.
What happened?
I don't know, sir. I was coming along the corridor and I heard him screaming.
Is he dead?
Yes, he's dead.
Probably a heart attack. Delayed shock from seeing the process.
Perhaps, but I doubt it. Might I suggest an immediate investigation into his past medical history and a post mortem.
Yes. Yes, a good idea. I'll see to it right away. Get a stretcher, will you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Summers leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor? Did you see his face? He looks terrified. And those marks, like
Bites and scratches? Yes, I know.
Look, I think we'd better get on to the Brigadier.
Yes, I agree, Jo, but not just yet. Now, let me get that post mortem first. It'll give me more to go on.
All right. Anyway, I don't think he'd thank us for disturbing him right now.
Hmm?
He did tell you all about it, Doctor.
All about what?
Today's the first ever World Peace Conference. UNIT's handling all the security arrangements.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: This time he has managed to requisition a very posh room with big double doors, fancy fireplace and large potted ficus.

Dialogue.Line: (on phone) Yes, that's all very well, sir, but in my opinion.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates enters.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, I see, sir. Of course, sir. I take it that is your final decision? Very well, sir, goodbye.
Trouble, sir?
That was the Ministry. UNIT'll be responsible for the safe transport of the missile. It's been cleared with Geneva.
Well, that's all we needed. What with the peace conference on our hands as well.
Yes. I want you to take charge of this escort detail, Captain Yates. I've got quite enough on my plate as it is.
I'll get onto it right away.
Oh, is the Doctor back from Stangmoor yet?
No sir. Er, what exactly is he doing down there?
Observing new development in the treatment of criminals, I believe. Oh well, I suppose it'll keep him out of mischief. By the way, how are things at the conference?
Oh, all running smoothly, sir.
I only hope it lasts.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Chinese woman officer bursts in, followed by a female UNIT officer - Bell.

Dialogue.Line: All right, Corporal Bell. Yes, Captain Chin Lee, what can I do for you?
Brigadier, an outrage has been committed against the Chinese people's delegation. As you are in charge of security arrangements, we hold you directly responsible.
What is it now, Captain?
Important state documents have been stolen from General Cheng Teik's suite.
That's impossible. There's a twenty four hour guard on all the delegate's suites.
Nevertheless, the theft has occurred. Your guards are inefficient. Perhaps they take bribes?
That is an insulting suggestion, Captain. I will not tolerate any! Very well, Captain, I'll investigate the matter immediately.
I must warn you that this puts the success of the peace conference in grave jeopardy. We suspect the imperialist Americans of this crime.
Naturally. I assure you that every effort will be made to locate the missing papers and to punish whoever is responsible.
Any further trouble and our delegation will withdraw from this conference.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chin Lee leaves.

Dialogue.Line: More trouble.
Mmm, pity. She's quite a dolly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chin Lee leaves 24 Cornwall Gardens and walks straight past the limousine waiting for her. She goes to the Green in middle of the area and takes a document from her jacket. She removes it's ribbon and sets fire to it then drops it into a waste paper basket at the last moment. Then she flinches and touches a round metal device just behind her right ear before leaving the scene.

Dialogue.Line: And you are still convinced this Keller process is working normally?
Yes, of course it is. I mean, you've just seen Barnham.
Yes. Yes, I've seen him.
Look, Emil Keller himself installed it here. I worked closely with him. I know every facet of the process.
Yes, I know. But I still don't like it.
What?
Interfering with the mind, Governor. It's a dangerous business.
Well, it's hardly your concern, is it?
Professor Kettering, it is everyone's concern!
After you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo and Summers enter.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, Doctor Summers. Any news for us?
I've got the post mortem report.
: Well?
The deceased's name was Arthur Linwood, a medical student in his final year.
Yes, yes, yes, but what did he die of?
Heart failure.
Watching the process was too much for him.
But he didn't have a weak heart, Mister Kettering.
Anything in his medical history?
Yes, I called his hospital. He suffered from a fear of certain animals.
Oh, which ones?
Well, apparently, in the laboratory he was absolutely terrified of
Rats?
Yes.
Tell me, these marks on his face on his face and neck, these bites and scratches, could they have been caused by rats?
Certainly they could, yes.
But there are no rats in this room. There's none in the entire prison.
Yet all the indications are that he was attacked by a hoard of them, and the shock killed him.
You must be mistaken.
But Linwood is dead.
Because of heart failure!
No, Professor Kettering, because of this machine.
I tell you that man's death had nothing to do with this machine, and if you were a scientist you'd understand.
If I were a scientist? Let me tell you, sir, that I am a scientist, and I have been for several thousand. Jo.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves.

Dialogue.Line: The man's mad.
On the contrary, sir, he happens to be a genius. I do wish you'd listen to him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Victor?
I think you'd better give this machine a thorough check, Professor Kettering.
Yes, of course, Governor. But I assure you there's no reason for anxiety.
All the same, better safe than sorry?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates and Bell are both on telephone when the Brigadier enters.

Dialogue.Line: I'll give you the final security schedules just as soon as I've had a chance to clear them with the Brigadier.
A call for you on line one, sir.
Oh, put it through, will you?
Right, right, I'll ring you back within twenty minutes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Another telephone rings.

Dialogue.Line: UNIT HQ? Oh, good morning, sir.
Yes, certainly Captain, I'm just
Lethbridge Stewart? I see. You're sure? Very well, continue the search. (into intercom) Captain Yates, will you come in for a moment please?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates enters.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, sit down. Well, there's no trace of Chin Lee's missing papers. Our people have turned the place inside out. It wouldn't surprise me if she lost them herself.
Excuse me, sir. Captain Chin Lee on the phone. Do you want to speak to her?
Yes, I'll speak to her.
Hotline, sir.
I wonder what she's complaining of this time? Yes, good afternoon, Captain Chin Lee. What can I do for you? Yes, I see. No, don't touch anything. I'll be over at once.
More stolen papers, sir?
(into intercom.) Get my car ready at once.
Right, sir.
We've got real trouble this time. The Chinese delegate's dead.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In the Process Theatre, the reservoir dial flickers as Kettering takes a panel off the control console. Then he puts his hands to his head as the machine starts to hum.

Dialogue.Line: All right men, keep that noise down.
Starting up again, are they?
Just like before. I don't what it is.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The machine is humming loudly as Kettering 'sees' a vast expanse of open water. He moves his arms as if swimming.

Dialogue.Line: No, no.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Then he raises his arms above his head as he sinks to the floor. The machine shuts itself off. Later, he is lying on a stretcher. Summers puts the blanket over Kettering's face and orderlies carry him away.

Dialogue.Line: Dead. Do you know how it happened, Roland?
I'm not sure. It's incredible, really.
Oh, come on, man, come on.
From the position of the body, tinge of the skin
Well?
All the symptoms are consistent with death by drowning.
But that's ridiculous!
Like the rats?
Shall I go and check on his medical record?
Yes, a good idea. How long would you say he'd been dead?
Oh, a matter of minutes, five at the outside.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Summers leaves.

Dialogue.Line: That must have been about the time the riot started.
Yes, exactly.
Are you suggesting there's some connection?
This machine has the power to affect men's minds, Governor, and it's growing stronger.
Oh, come now, Doctor. It's only a machine.
Yes, maybe, but nevertheless it's dangerous and it should be destroyed now!
Well, I've no authority to do that. I'll report your recommendations to the Home Office but they'll have to decide.
I wonder how many deaths it'll take to convince them?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Another body is covered over. Photographs are being taken of the mess caused by an apparent struggle.

Dialogue.Line: First theft, Brigadier, now murder. What are you going to do about it?
Who else knows about this?
No one. I called you at once.
Shall I call the police. sir?
Yes, just a courtesy call, but tell them we'll handle this ourselves. And I want a full check on all movements in and out of this suite before Cheng Teik's death. And no press. 'D' notice.
Right, sir.
And get the Doctor back from Stangmoor, will you? I want him here.
Yes, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Now then, Captain. I'd like you to tell me exactly what happened, please? In detail.
My appointment with the General was for twelve pm. There were some details to discuss about the conference.
And you were punctual?
I am always punctual. I showed my pass to your UNIT sentry and entered as the clock was striking twelve.
Go on.
There is nothing more to tell. I saw the General's body and phoned you.
Immediately?
Of course.
Excuse me a moment, will you? Oh, Corporal Bell? I'd like you to.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Brigadier looks at Chin Lee, who moves away a little.

Dialogue.Line: (sotto) I want you to make an exact check on the time of Chin Lee's phone call.
Right, sir.
I'm sorry, Doctor. That's my final word. I'll suspend further use of the Keller process, I'll put this room out of bounds. But that's all I can do without higher authority.
Yes. Yes, all right. Well, I'd better make this machine safe.
Can I help?
On my own.
Is that wise?
Perhaps not.
Well then
But I prefer to work that way. Tell me, how long has this machine been installed?
Nearly a year. Emil Keller came over from Switzerland to supervise the installation.
I see. Did he have an assistant?
Mmm hmm. A rather attractive Chinese girl.
(into phone) Yes. Mmm. Yes, right. Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bell gives the Brigadier a note.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you. You telephoned me immediately?
Yes.
No, Captain, you didn't. You telephoned me at exactly twelve twenty four.
You must be mistaken.
You called me on a security line. All security calls are logged. Well, Captain? Why did you wait for nearly half an hour before reporting the crime?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barnham wakes, and the orderly fetches Summers from the little office.

Dialogue.Line: How do you feel?
Fine. Fine. Have I been ill?
Yes, but you're all right now.
Are you a doctor?
Mmm hmm. Don't you remember? I'm Doctor Summers. Just try and rest. You'll be all right.
Anything you say, Doctor.
Well, he seems fully recovered, physically.
And mentally?
Well, his memory's a bit hazy but it's only to be expected.
And has the process harmed him?
I, I don't know, Miss Grant.
The Doctor was wondering about Mister Kettering's medical history?
Oh, yes, I've got the post mortem report through there.
What's the verdict?
Kettering's lungs were full of water. He drowned in the middle of a perfectly dry room.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor tries to shield himself from the flames as Jo enters.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor? What's the matter? Let's sit down. It's all right, there's nothing there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The machine has stopped but the Doctor is still gibbering with fear.

Dialogue.Line: There's nothing there. Come and sit. There's nothing, Doctor. It's me, Jo. It's all right.
Jo. Jo, what are you doing here?
Well, you wanted this report on Kettering. I got it from Doctor Summers.
Look, I told you to take that directly to the Governor's office.
I thought it was important.
So are my instructions, Jo. So are my instructions. You might have been killed.
Me killed? It seemed that you were the one in danger. You looked as if you were fighting something that wasn't there.
Well, it was there, Jo. At least it was until you distracted it. Your coming in broke its grip on my mind. Let me see that report.
You were right about Kettering. He did have a morbid fear of water.
So he drowned in a perfectly dry room.
Doctor, what did you see?
Fire.
But why should you?
Well, some time ago, Jo, I witnessed a terrible catastrophe. A whole world just, just disappeared in flames. Well, this machine picked that memory out of my mind and used it to attack me.
This fire you saw, it wasn't real.
Neither was the water, nor the rats, yet Linwood is dead and so is Professor Kettering. We believe what our minds tell us to, Jo.
If this machine's so dangerous, why not just blow it up? Destroy it.
Because those idiots in authority won't let me, that's why. I'm trying to find a way of controlling it. So, if you've quite finished asking questions?
All right, I'm going.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates enters.

Dialogue.Line: Mike? What are you doing here?
The Brigadier's orders. I'm afraid, Doctor, you've got to come back to London with me.
Nonsense. I can't possibly leave Stangmoor.
You've got to, Doctor.
I'm telling you I'm not leaving.
I'm sorry, Doctor. You're coming back with me, even if I have to use force.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates takes hold of the Doctor's arm and receives a forefinger below the collar bone for his trouble. He can't move.

Dialogue.Line: Venusian Karate. I think you'll find that a lot harder than you imagine, young man.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor lets Yates go.

Dialogue.Line: Look, Doctor, he really does need you. Things are going very badly at the peace conference. The Chinese delegate's dead and we think he's been murdered.
Murdered? Yes, all right, Captain Yates. I'll come with you.
Thank you.
Doctor? I'll say here and look after things for you.
Look, Jo, for once in your young life, do you think you could do exactly as I ask?
Yes, of course.
Now go and see the Governor. Tell him to lock and bar that door. No one is to enter this room. No one. Do you understand?
Just leave everything to me.
Yes. Yes, I'm rather afraid I'll have to. Try and keep out of trouble, will you?
Yes, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves, but Jo is holding his clock.

Dialogue.Line: Come along, Captain Yates, what are you waiting for?
Doctor! Mike.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chin Lee is in a telephone box as Benton, dressed in civvies, is keeping an eye on her. She steps out of the box and stares at Benton, who staggers against a railing, clutching his head in pain. We are given an image of the Keller machine pulsing away. As Benton collapses, a man rushes over to help him. Chin Lee leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Are you all right?
Yes. Yes, I'm all right, thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benton starts to run after Chin Lee and falls down before staggering on again. The machine shuts itself off again. Benton gets to UNIT HQ without spotting Chin Lee hiding behind a workman's tent.

Dialogue.Line: You lost her?
Yes, sir. She gave me the slip. One minute I had her well in sight and next she just
She vanished in a puff of smoke.
No, sir. I got this sort of throbbing in my head. I guess I fainted. When I came to, she'd gone.
Throbbing in the head? Fainting? You're too delicate for intelligence work, Benton. You'd better go and lie down.
Right, sir. Sorry, sir.
Dismissed, Sergeant. Just get out of my sight.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Yates enter as Benton leaves.

Dialogue.Line: I see you're in your usual sweet affable mood, Brigadier.
When you've quite finished grinning like a Cheshire cat, Captain Yates!
Sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Right, now, Brigadier, would you kindly tell me what all this fuss is about?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benton leaves the building, and we are treated to a view of a telephone engineer working in a junction box. He switches on a hand-held device then packs up and goes back to the tent where he turns it on again.
Yates is on the telephone. He takes it from his ear then tries again.

Dialogue.Line: Mister Curry, are you still there? Oh good. No, no, for a moment I thought we'd been cut off.
As I was saying, the escort will be under my command and will consist of myself, a Sergeant and four motorcycle outriders.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The engineer removes his mask and overalls. It is the Master.

Dialogue.Line: It's a bit light, isn't it, Captain, considering the importance of this weapon.
We'll only make ourselves conspicuous if we surround it with a small army, won't we?
Oh, all right. I suppose you people know best.
Our ETA with you will be at oh eight fifteen hours.
And you will let me know the route?
Yes, I'll ring you through with the route as soon as it's finalised. Goodbye, sir.
Goodbye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master turns off the radio, picks up his coat and briefcase, and walks across the square to a chauffeur driven car. Once settled inside he switches on the radio again.

Dialogue.Line: All right, all right, all right, all right, Doctor! You win.
And you'll back up my report to the Home Office calling for a complete ban on the Keller process.
Yes.
And you'll get in touch with the Home Secretary and make sure that he takes some action.
Yes, Doctor, and if that doesn't do any good, I personally will go down to Stangmoor and blow the blasted machine up myself. Now, are you or are you not going to help me with this case?
My dear Lethbridge Stewart, your word is my command. You know that you only have to ask.
Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Brigadier gets his briefcase.

Dialogue.Line: Well, where on earth do you think you're going?
We are going to see the new Chinese delegate, Mister Fu Peng.
Fu Peng? He must be Hokien.
No, no, no, Doctor. He's Chinese. Now, come along.
Excuse me.
Later!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Brigadier leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, it's going to be one of those days. Cheshire cat, Captain Yates, Cheshire cat.
Doctor!
Yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, I'm coming.
(into phone) Get me transport, will you?
Transport?
Captain Yates here. I'd like you to lay on a motorcycle escort of four and a jeep for oh seven hundred hours tomorrow.
Right-o, sir. Where's your rendezvous, sir?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master watches the Doctor and Brigadier walk along Cornwall Gardens.

Dialogue.Line: Here at HQ. I'll take the party down myself.
Right-o, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fu Peng is reading a newspaper when the Brigadier and Doctor are shown in. He ignores them.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, Mister Fu Peng? I'm Brigadier Lethbridge Stewart of UNIT command. I'm in charge of all security arrangements. And this is our scientific advisor.
(in Hokien) This unworthy person welcomes you and delights in your safe arrival.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fu Peng stands and replies in the same language.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you for your courtesy and welcome. It is I who am delighted to meet such a charming person in this barbaric country. (in English) It is rare to meet a westerner who knows my language.
Oh, thank you. Actually I fear my Hokien is somewhat rusty.
On the contrary, it is excellent.
Well, it's many years since I've had a chance to use it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The aide brings a chair for the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: I remember once having a conversation with Tse-Tung.
Tse-Tung? But that is the personal name of our chairman, Mao Tse- Tung.
He himself gave me leave to use it.
Yes, if we could just discuss the immediate problem.
You will take some tea?
Kam si ya.
Tang pei lai. Sing- sen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chatting happily in Hokien, Fu Peng and the Doctor go into an inner room, leaving the Brigadier to sit alone on the empty chair.
A prisoner is being taken from his cell.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, Mailer, out you come. Get behind me there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Another prisoner with a mop and box of cleaning items is let through the grill to the side corridor and Barnham's old cell.

Dialogue.Line: Right, Vosper, come on.
Right, Vosper, get busy. I want this place cleaned up properly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barnham is listening to the radio on headphones as the Keller machine starts up again.

Dialogue.Line: Hello.
How is he?
Fit as a fiddle, aren't you, Barnham? Barnham.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barnham takes off the headphones.

Dialogue.Line: Visitor for you. Pull up a chair.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo sits and hands Barnham a pack of Dairy Box.

Dialogue.Line: Hello.
Thank you. Do I know you?
Well, we've sort of met.
It's just that I can't seem to remember anybody or anything very well.
Don't you remember being treated by the Keller machine?
It's all a bit of a blank, I'm afraid. Do you know, you wouldn't believe this, but I couldn't even remember me own name. Not until the Doctor there told me.
Well, I'm glad to see you looking so much better. Bye.
Thanks very much for the chocolates, Miss.
Well, everything seems all right.

Don't argue, Mailer, do it. Then meet me in the Governor's office when it's finished.
Yes. Sir.
You hang on here, Len, yeah?
Yeah, I'll be here.
Hey! Hey, you out there! Listen to me! We need help urgently.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Vosper opens the inspection hatch.

Dialogue.Line: Go to sleep, darling.
Look, open this door. Please, open this door!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Vosper enters.

Dialogue.Line: A proper little Miss Nightingale, ain't you?
Look at him. He needs a doctor.
Pity.
Help me! Well, at least help me get him up onto the bed.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The reservoir dial on the humming machine reads Full.

Dialogue.Line: You can't harm me. I'm stronger than you are.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a battle of wills.

Dialogue.Line: I brought you here. I gave you the minds you need to feed on! You are my servant! You are my servant! I

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master is losing the battle. He goes to the control panel but the machine will not switch off. The Master is confronted with his greatest fear - the Doctor laughing at him.

Dialogue.Line: No! No! You can't destroy me! I am too strong for you! I am too strong for you!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master flees, barring the door again. The prisoners are groaning.

Dialogue.Line: No more minds for you to feed on. Let's see how long starvation takes to bring you to heel.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Doctor Summers is listening to the Doctor's hearts in amazement.

Dialogue.Line: It's extraordinary. Quite extraordinary. His physical make-up, it's just not human.
But what's the matter with him?
He's been beaten up, of course, physically and mentally. His whole system's suffered a tremendous shock. He's in some kind of a coma, but I
Can't you do anything for him?
I very much doubt it. You could try giving him one of these, if he recovers consciousness.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Summers gives Jo a bottle of tablets.

Dialogue.Line: (sotto) Listen, Jo, who organised this break?
Right, Doc, time's up. What's the verdict? He done for?
Not quite. Though it's no thanks to you.
Come on, Doc. Don't forget to send in your bill. Charlie?
Take care, hmm?
And you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Charlie lets Vosper and Summers out of the cell. The Doctor moans.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor? Doctor, take one of these. Come on. Come on, just try.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo can't get the tablet in the Doctor's mouth.

Dialogue.Line: That's wrong, wrong metabolism. It'd probably kill me, Jo. I'm all right. I'm all right, Jo. Just, just let me rest. Let me rest.
Doctor. Please.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master is exhausted and mopping his brow when Mailer enters.

Dialogue.Line: All right, fixed that. Here, you all right?
Yes, yes, of course, of course.
You don't look any too good to me.
Mailer, I want a guard on that process room the whole time. No one's to go near that machine. No one.
I don't think any of my lot are likely to.
Yes, I know, but morbid curiosity can be very strong. See to it, will you? Mailer! Mailer, you've done very well. I'm pleased with you.
Good. Then, er, perhaps you'd like to do something for me?
Why, certainly. Anything.
Perhaps you'd like to tell me why the hell we don't get out of here before it gets light.
My dear Mailer, you are just not thinking. A great gang of armed convicts roaming round the countryside?
If we can get our civvies back, there's cars outside.
Yes, maybe. But have you thought that as well as the police, you'd have the army against you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master sets up a small slide projector and screen and turns out the lights.

Dialogue.Line: Dogs, troops, helicopters. Heh! By morning, you'd all be captured or killed.
Yeah, all right. So, you've got a better idea?
I think so, yes. How would you like a free pardon, unlimited money and a ticket to anywhere in the world?
How would I like it? Do me a favour.
Right, pay attention. I'll show you how to get it. Now, that is Thunderbolt. It's a gas missile, nuclear powered and British, of course.
Of course.

The most important thing is that it's illegal, because gas warfare's been outlawed for many years. Therefore the British government are going to dump that in the sea. Now, tomorrow morning, that missile, with a very small escort, will pass within a few miles of this prison.
I see, and you'd like me to hijack it?
Right first time.
Eh?
I'm going to aim that at the peace conference in London.
You've got to be joking.
I am not joking. You look at this map. Now, here's the prison, and this is where you will ambush the convoy.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo has slept in a chair. She wakes when Vosper enters.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor? Doctor?
Morning. Oh, he's still with us then.
Sorry you're disappointed.
You watch your tongue.
How about some breakfast?
What do you think this is, a holiday camp?
You weren't told to starve us to death. What good do you think he's going to be to the Master is he doesn't have any food inside him!
All right, all right. Charlie!
Yeah?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Charlie enters.

Dialogue.Line: Nip down the kitchens, get some grub for these two.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Charlie leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Though by the look of him I don't think he's going to need it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Vosper leaves. Jo sits and the Doctor gets up.

Dialogue.Line: Well done, my dear. Now perhaps we can do something about getting out of here.
Remember, if you're successful, this will be your passport to freedom. Anywhere! All right, good luck to you.
Everybody got the picture? All right then, let's go. Now come along, move!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The armed prisoners get into the back of the police van.

Dialogue.Line: (eating a piece of toast) Here's your grub then. I'll watch the door, Charlie.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Vosper leaves as Charlie enters with a tray.

Dialogue.Line: I thought that was meant to be for us?
It's all right, there's
Thanks.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo reaches for the tray then slams it into Charlie's face before giving him a karate chop to the back of the neck.

Dialogue.Line: Charlie? Charlie, what's the matter?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo gives the Doctor the tray and they stand either side of the door as Vosper enters.

Dialogue.Line: What the devil's going on here?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor hits Vosper over the head, Jo takes the gun and they leave.
The Doctor locks the cell door.

Dialogue.Line: Really, Doctor, for someone who was on death's door.
I do have remarkable powers of recovery, don't I? Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The room is still in darkness. Jo looks out of the window.

Dialogue.Line: They seem to be setting up some kind of search party.
They'll be expecting us to try and make a break for it.
Well, aren't we?
No, not while they're all chasing around. Let them cool off for a bit. We'll try again later.
Telephone. There must be a telephone here somewhere.
There is, but it's locked.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The telephone is in a wooden box.

Dialogue.Line: In any case, it'll be manned by convicts.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo turns on the slide projector.

Dialogue.Line: What's that?
That, my dear Jo, is the Thunderbolt. Captain Yates is escorting it. I hope.
What's it got to do with the Master?
Everything. He's hoping to steal it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mailer leads his men to the ambush point.

Dialogue.Line: Get down!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The prisoners are down behind the fence.

Dialogue.Line: Right, now don't forget. Wait till they get level before you let them have it.
Here they come.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two motorcycles followed by a Land Rover come into view. The truck with the missile is behind them. The prisoners open fire. The motorcyclists fall, then the Land Rover swerves into a ditch and the driver - Benton, apparently - falls out. The police van is driven out to block the truck and the Sergeant driving it is killed. Yates runs to safety.

Dialogue.Line: Venus to Jupiter, Venus to Jupiter. Convoy under armed attack. Estimated position

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates is shot.

Dialogue.Line: Jupiter to Venus. Jupiter to Venus, give us your position. I say again, give us your position! Over.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Static.

Dialogue.Line: Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates starts to recover, and gets the damaged radio.

Dialogue.Line: Venus to Jupiter. Do you read me? Over.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates crawls along the hedge-line to see what is happening. The prisoners are returning to the police van.

Dialogue.Line: Venus to Jupiter, do you read me? Over.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The police van, truck and missile are driven away. Yates runs over to the Land Rover to see Benton starting to move, then gets one of the motorcycles and follows the thieves. Benton starts to get up then passes out again.

Dialogue.Line: The last time he checked in, he was here. Now, given the average speed of the convoy and the time of the emergency call, the ambush should have taken place about here. I want a chopper standing by to take me down there as soon as possible.
I'll get on to it right away, sir.
And I'll need a mobile HQ and a full forensic team in the area.
Extension three four. Shall I ask for police and army co-operation, sir?
No, UNIT personnel only. This missile isn't supposed to exist. Keep trying to get through to Captain Yates.
Right sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Brigadier leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Jupiter to Venus. Jupiter to Venus. Do you read me? Over.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates follows the convoy onto what is labelled as MOD property where they park up by a hangar.

Dialogue.Line: All right, let's get these doors open. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: We see military personnel unhitching the missile from its trailer.

Dialogue.Line: Come on. In!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates watches the police van drive off, leaving the missile in the care of the army and a small group of prisoners. They spot him riding away and shoot. He falls and the bike crashes into a handy pile of crates. The prisoners run over and drag Yates away.
Benton has had his head bandaged and is now being interrogated.

Dialogue.Line: Is that all you can tell me?
It happened so quickly, sir.
Did you see what happened to Captain Yates?
I thought they'd got him.
Not unless they took the body with them. One of the bikes is missing.
Well, maybe he followed them, sir.
Yes, maybe. Right, thanks.
There's just one thing, sir.
Well?
Just before I passed out, I could have sworn I saw a plain black van. The sort the police use. A black Maria.
Map! Thank you. Stangmoor prison.
What, sir?
Well, where else would you get a Black Maria?
Doctor, we can just go on sitting here.
Why not? It's the safest place at the moment. They'll never think of looking for us here. Besides, I need more time to think. I've got to find out a way of dealing with that alien creature out there.
What alien creature?
The one inside the Keller machine.
Do you really believe there's something alive in there?
I do.
Well, what is it?
It's a sort of mind parasite that feeds on evil. The deadliest threat to mankind since the beginning of time.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo looks out the window.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor.
Mmm?
The Master. He seems to be leaving.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master gets into his chauffeur driven car.

Dialogue.Line: Right. Now's our chance.
We'll slip out by the hospital and through the rear courtyard.
I didn't mean our chance to escape, Jo. I meant our chance to get into that process chamber and deal with that machine once and for all.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo offers the Doctor the gun.

Dialogue.Line: No, thank you. You were trained to use those things. They only make me nervous.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But in the Process Theatre, the Keller machine starts up and then vanishes.

Charlie is searching the cells when the machine appears beside him. He tries shooting at it, then screams and falls dead. The machine disappears. Jo and the Doctor enter down a small spiral staircase.

Dialogue.Line: His face! He looks terrified, just like the others.
Perhaps the creature's learned to move. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Keller machine vanishes.

Dialogue.Line: What happened? Why did it just disappear?
Well, we couldn't have tempted its appetite.
Why not?
Well, I imagine it detected a higher concentration of evil in Mailer. There's something to be said for a pure mind, after all, eh, Jo?
Look, I think we'd better get out of here before it gets back!
Yes, all right, Jo! Jo! Wait a minute. Wait.
Barnham! What are you doing here?
Well, I was looking for you. I heard this noise and
It's all right. We're going to try and escape.
I don't understand.
Look, we've got to stop the Master from launching that missile. Now come on, Barnham, you come with us.
Come on. Quickly! Come on!
Windmill three four seven
To Trap One. How do you read me? Over.
Acknowledge that, will you, Sergeant? Trap One to Windmill three four seven. Major Cosworth reading you loud and clear. Any results? Over.
I'm over Stangmoor Prison now. No sign of the missile. Everything seems quiet and normal. Over.
Are you going to land? Over.
No, I don't think so. I know I said it seems normal but I'm quite sure it's not. I'll continuing reccying for the moment. Over and out.
Well, there doesn't seem to be anybody about. Let's take a look outside. (to Barnham) You wait here for a minute.
Hey, look! It's the UNIT helicopter! Hey!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Jo wave.

Dialogue.Line: All right, you two. Inside!
Move!
Don't hurt them.
Leave off, Barnham. I said move.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barnham stands close up to the prisoner and takes hold of the rifle in both hands. They struggle, but Barnham is easily the stronger.

Dialogue.Line: I said don't hurt them.
No, no, Barnham.
Let him go. Let him go!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor stops Barnham from crushing the prisoners windpipe by a Venusian karate move.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, let's get out of here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two more armed prisoners arrive.

Dialogue.Line: But they were trying to

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mailer is on the telephone.

Dialogue.Line: What the hell do you mean, we loused things up? You got your missile, didn't you?
You left one of the UNIT people alive and he followed you here. Fortunately, he was caught.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates is tied up in a chair, unconscious.

Dialogue.Line: Look, I don't care about him. I want you back here right away!
That's quite impossible. I'm far too busy preparing the missile for launching.
Look, mate, I don't care how busy you are. I want you back. That machine of yours has broken out. It's wandering around the prison. It's killed Lenny Vosper. It's nearly killed me!
That's impossible, I can't leave here now.
Now listen. My mob's not staying on here while that thing's on the loose. They'll start running and I'll be running with them.
But you can't! You'll be caught!
Maybe. But just remember
If I get caught, so do you. They'll want to know where that missile is and I might just tell them. Now think about it!
I see. All right, Mailer. I'll come back.
That's more like it.
All right, Captain. You can stop pretending to be unconscious now.
Why? Why
Why did I take the missile? I intend to use it.
You'll never be able to. It's too complex.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master shows Yates a control panel.

Dialogue.Line: Nonsense! This is childishly simple. Anyhow, I have all the technical assistance I need.
Yes, I was going to ask you. About those soldiers.
Hired mercenaries in fake uniforms. Everything's a question of money nowadays, my dear Captain. Will you excuse me? Oh, by the way, you're probably wondering why you're still alive.
It did cross my mind.
Well, in the event, in the highly unlikely event of UNIT finding us before the missile's ready, you'd make a very useful hostage. Remember that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master leaves and Yates starts to try and get himself free.

Dialogue.Line: Right, come on.
Where did you find them?
Outside B wing, waving to a helicopter.
You what? Did it see them?
Nah, I don't think so. Anyway, it's cleared off now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mailer points at Barnham.

Dialogue.Line: Get that zombie out of here. Get rid of him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fuller pushes Barnham out of the room.

Dialogue.Line: I don't know what we're going to do about you.
Look, Mailer, what
Back off.
Mailer, why are you helping the Master?
Helping who?
The Ma, er, er, Keller or whatever he calls himself.
Simple. I'm helping him because he's helping me.
Oh, what's he promised you?
Money, pardon, ticket to anywhere I like.
Do you really think he's going to keep those promises?
Why not?
He doesn't care whether you live or die. He's just using you.
So he's using me, I'm using him. You make me a better offer?
Let us go and I'll do the best I can for you.
Well, if that's the best you can do, Doc, it really ain't good enough. Now, wheel 'em out.
Right, come on.
I know exactly where that missile is. Here.
Stangmoor Prison, sir?

It all adds up. Benton saw a Black Maria when the missile was ambushed and I saw the Doctor and Miss Grant. I'm convinced the Master has taken over the prison to be used as a hideout for that missile.
Then I assume we'll be taking the place, sir. I'll draw up an assault plan.
Major Cosworth?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: with a curtain for a door

Dialogue.Line: Sir?
Have you seen Stangmoor Prison?
No, sir.
Well, I've just been looking at it. It's an old fortress. You'd need an army to get in there.
A fortress?
That's right.
I suppose there couldn't possible be a secret underground passage or something?
Good, Major, good. Is that a map of the prison?
Yes, sir.
Yes, you're right. It hasn't been blocked off either. It probably leads to the old dungeons.
It's rather like making a film, isn't it, sir.
Greyhound seven to Trap One. Greyhound seven to Trap One.
Excuse me, sir.
It's all right, I'll take it. Go ahead, Greyhound seven.
A black saloon car has just entered the prison gates. Over.
Thank you, Greyhound seven. Maintain surveillance. Over and out.
It must be the Master. They wouldn't let anyone else inside. Right, that settles it! We're going to take that prison.
By using the underground passage?
Yes. And also by using a Trojan Horse.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Jo are playing draughts.

Dialogue.Line: I must say, you've taken your time about it.
Yes
Any trouble?
Not a squeak out of them.
All right. Open up, Fuller.
Doctor, I
Shush, shush, shush, shush. (The Doctor takes one of Jo's red pieces.)
There.
Doctor, I
Shush.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo takes all the Doctor's remaining pieces.

Dialogue.Line: There.
Yes, well, the trouble with this game is that it's too simple. In any case, I'm more used to playing three dimensional chess.
All right, I've allowed you your little gesture. Now perhaps we can talk seriously.
I suppose you're going to ask me to control that machine of yours again.
I am.
Yes, well, I can't. I've told you before. Nobody can.
You underestimate yourself, Doctor. You are perfectly capable of controlling it. For a time, at least.
Well, even if I could, why should I help you?
To save lives. Several people have died already.
Yeah. Most of them hard cases that were helping you.
Very well, then. To save one life.
My own?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master looks at Jo.

Dialogue.Line: Don't listen to him, Doctor. He's just bluffing.
Am I? Unless the Doctor does what I ask, Miss Grant, Mailer will shoot you here and now.
Well, it's only a theory, but I think there may be one way to inhibit that machine's power of movement.
And now is your chance to put that theory to the test.
Well where's the thing now? Still wandering about?
Gone back to the process chamber.
Temporarily glutted, no doubt.
Well, I shall need a lot of equipment, you know.
Oh, Stangmoor Prison's a very progressive place. The entire contents of the workshop's at your disposal.
All right, I'll give it a try.
Good. All right, Fuller. Let us out, will you? No, Miss Grant. You will stay here as a guarantee of the Doctor's good behaviour. After you, Doctor. Satisfied, Mailer?
Now we shall, as you realise, be very considerably outnumbered. However, not all of our opponents will be armed and none of them will be trained soldiers.
And, of course, we shall have surprise on our side.
Exactly. Any questions?
No, sir.
Right, carry on.
An excellent plan, if I may say so, sir. A very good chance of success.
Thank you, Major Cosworth. I'm very relieved to hear that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A knock on the dividing partition.

Dialogue.Line: Yes?
Excuse me, sir.
Benton? What the devil are you doing here? You're supposed to be in hospital.
Well, yes, sir. I discharged myself. I'm all right now. I've just got a bit of a sore head.
I'll just get on, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Cosworth leaves.

Dialogue.Line: At ease, Sergeant. Well, what do you want?
I'd like to come on the assault, sir.
Benton, you're supposed to be suffering from severe concussion.
I know, sir, but it's only a scratch, honest. And you said yourself, I've got a thick skull. Anyway, I'd like a chance to get at the blokes who did it.
All right. If you feel fit, you can take charge of the underground assault party. Major Cosworth will put you in the picture.
Thank you, sir. Sir, I
Yes?
Well, I wondered if you'd had any news about Captain Yates, sir.
I'm sorry, Benton, there's nothing. Nothing at all.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates manages to break the ropes holding him, but then pretends to be out cold again when a prisoner comes to check on him. The prisoner leans over and Yates grabs his head, throwing him to the floor. Then he takes the pistol and leaves.
As the machine sits in the process theatre across the hallway, its reservoir full of black thoughts, the Doctor is fixing up a large coil of cable.

Dialogue.Line: Look, Doctor, you must hurry! If that thing in there starts moving again
I'm well aware of the urgency of the situation, thank you. Right. Excuse me, will you?
Oh.
Would you mind bringing that plug with you, please?
Oh, right.
And the coil.
Yeah.
Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They go to a trolley with a large battery-like box on it. There is a slider and several switches on it.

Dialogue.Line: Look, tell me, what precisely do you intend to do?
I'm going to try throwing this coil over that machine in there. If I can get close enough to it without being killed, that is.
I see. Well, what can I do to help.
Well, I want you to operate these controls here and switch on to full power when I call out.
This is very ingenious.
If all goes well, it should set up an electric current in the coil alternating on much the same frequency as the beta rhythms of the human brain.
And you think that'll deal with it?
I don't know, but I think it'll confuse the creature enough to take away its power of movement anyway.
Well, I hope you are right.
So do I.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master plugs the cable into the box, while the Doctor puts on protective clothing.

Dialogue.Line: Now switch it on now, will you? Bottom one.
Right. Well, good luck to you, Doctor.
Thank you. Right, you know what to do.
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor kicks open the doors and sidles in carefully. As he gets close, the machine starts up and the coil that the Doctor is holding begins to spit sparks. The nightmare images return as the Doctor struggles to get the coil close to the machine.

Dialogue.Line: Exterminate! Annihilate! Destroy! Exterminate! Annihilate! Destroy! Exterminate!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He slams it down over the body of the machine.

Dialogue.Line: Now!
Annihilate!
Now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Outside, the Master pushes the slider across the front of the box. Finally the machine switches off and the Doctor removes his protective helmet and gloves.

Dialogue.Line: Mailer. Mailer? Well, Doctor. Congratulations.
It won't hold it for long, you know. That thing's intelligent. Soon it'll work out what happened and find a way to deal with it.
Then you'll have to think up something better, won't you. Now take the Doctor back to his cell, Mailer.
Let's go.
You all right, Doctor?
Yes, thank you, Jo. I'm fine, I'm fine.
Did you fix the machine?
Yes, temporarily.
You look tired.
I am. Physically and mentally.
Hey, how about some food? Do you think they'd let us have any?
I doubt it. Not after what happened last time.
I've had nothing to eat all day. I'm starving.
Well, we shouldn't have thrown our breakfast at them, should we?
Breakfast! Hey, wait a minute. I knew they wouldn't bother to clear up. Here you are.
Oh, no thanks, Jo, you have it. I'll do without food for a while.
No, we'll share it. And there's some water in the jug over here.
Oh, all right. Cheers.
Cheers.
Huh. Did I ever tell you about the time I was in the Tower of London?
No?
No?
No.
Well, I shared a cell with a very strange chap called Raleigh.
Raleigh?
Yeah, Sir Walter Raleigh.
Oh.

He got into some trouble with Queen Elizabeth. Elizabeth the first, that is. He kept going on about this new vegetable of his he'd discovered, you see, called the potato. One day, he sat down, pointed a finger at me

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A transit van arrives at the main gate and a man in overalls gets out to ring the bell. He whistles 'Colonel Bogey' while armed soldiers creep out of the back of the van. Eventually the prisoner dressed as a guard arrives.

Dialogue.Line: Morning, mate. Provisions.
What?
Provisions. Nosh. Food.
Back gate. You leave it at the inner gate. You can't come in here.
Oh, it won't get in there, mate. Me van's too big.
You'll have to clear off then.
'Ere, wait a minute. I've got a weeks supply of food in there, and booze for the Governor. Am I supposed to go back and tell them you don't want it? They'll think you're barmy.
Hang about. (into R/T) Main gate here. I've got a big provisions lorry. Do I let it in?
Yeah, okay. But I want him out of here fast.
Drive up the main courtyard. Unload there. We'll give you a hand. The, er, chief wants you out of here quick as possible.
Don't worry. Less time I spend in there, the better.
Okay, open up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Brigadier goes back to the van and drives it through the gateway, with the three soldiers following close behind. They take out the gate guards as they reach them.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, out!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: We watch from up on the motte as other soldiers get out of the van and run towards the inner ward. They go up a wooden stairway as the van is driven the long way round.
The van is met by two prisoners.

Dialogue.Line: The back's open.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The two prisoners are dealt with by the remaining troops. Shots are fired. The Brigadier gets a megaphone.

Dialogue.Line: This is Brigadier Lethbridge Stewart of UNIT. This prison is now in military hands.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A sniper shoots the megaphone out of his hand, so the Brigadier kills the man with a fast draw of his revolver.

Dialogue.Line: It seems to be right inside the prison.
Yes. I only hope they can gain complete control before Mailer starts killing the hostages.
So do I.
Hmm? Oh, yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Brigadier joins some of his men by the parked cars. He takes cover behind Bessie then spots a prisoner on the ramparts.

Dialogue.Line: There!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benson leads his squad for an assault on the bailey. Both sides take casualties, but more on the prisoners side than soldiers. When the shooting stops, the Brigadier waves in a UNIT Land Rover carrying reinforcements.

Dialogue.Line: Come on! I'm going to find the Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mailer enters, gun ready.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, come to give yourself up?
Now shut up and listen. You want to stay alive you'll do exactly as I say.
Well?
You're going to help me get out of here. You're going to walk out of here and tell those friends of yours that either I get out or I'm going to chop you down. All right?
They won't listen.
Too bad for you if they don't. Come on, move!
And remember, no heroics. I can get out with either one of you. Up!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Except it wasn't Mailer firing, it was the Brigadier. Mailer is dead.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you, Brigadier. But do you think that for once in your life you could manage to arrive before the nick of time?
I'm glad to see you too, Doctor. All right, Miss Grant?
Yes, thanks.
I see you've changed your job.
Yes. Rather an effective disguise, don't you think?
Right, down there.
Well, did you get the Master?
Sorry, sir. He seems to have got away.
What about the missile?
Well, we didn't
Isn't it here?
No.
Oh.
Yes, well, apart from losing the Master and the missile, you're doing very well, Brigadier.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: At the airfield, the Master's car has arrived behind the missile, which is part way out of the hangar. He gets out and nods, and the missile is aimed upwards. Back at Stangmoor, the Brigadier is setting up a mobile HQ in the Governor's office, complete with maps on walls and radio.

Dialogue.Line: Look, the Master has got to be found, Brigadier.
I'm rather more concerned with finding that missile.
Well, it comes to the same thing, surely.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benton enters, with Barnham under escort.

Dialogue.Line: Excuse me, sir?
Yes?
Everything's secure, sir. The prisoners are back in their cells and we're starting to move the wounded out.
Right, Sergeant Benton.
Oh, and we found this chap, sir, hiding in the medical block.
Lock him up with the others.
Right, sir.
No. No, no, don't. Come on, Barnham.
Right, Davies.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The soldier leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Come and sit down.
I heard, I heard the shooting and I didn't know what to do.
It's all right, it's all over. We'll take care of you. Has he been given anything to eat?
Well, no, Miss, we were going
Well, don't just stand there, show me where I can find him something.
Yes, Miss. Sorry.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo and Benton leave.

Dialogue.Line: Who is this man?

His name is Barnham. He's the last man to undergo the Keller process and you can see what it's done to him. He's got the mind of a child. Don't worry about him. You leave him to Jo. He trusts her. Right, let's take a look of this map of yours.
Trap One to Greyhound. Trap One to Greyhound.
It's Captain Yates.
All right, I'll take it. Greyhound to Trap One. Is that you, Yates? Where are you?
I'm at mobile HQ, sir.
What happened?
Quite a lot. I know where he's got Thunderbolt.
Where?
Outside a hanger on that deserted airfield at Stanham. He's got a crane, launching pad, fake troops, the lot.
Are you all right, Yates?
A bit bashed about, sir, but I might just survive.
Right, stay where you are. I'm on my way. Over and out. No need to worry about the Master any more. This time, we've got him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In the hangar office, the Master makes final adjustments to the Thunderbolt 2 control panel. Meanwhile, in the process theatre, the Keller machine burns out its control collar.

Dialogue.Line: Right, Sergeant Benton. You'll be in charge of the prison. You can consider yourself Acting Governor.
Thank you, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Brigadier gets up, and Benton takes over the Governor's chair.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, Benton?
Yes, sir?
Don't get any delusions of grandeur, will you?
No, sir.
Well, that about wraps it up, Doctor.
Mmm?
I said, that about wraps it up.
Does it?
Major Cosworth's throwing a cordon around that hangar now. I'll join him at mobile HQ and then we'll move in and mop things up.
You may not find the Master all that easy to mop up, Brigadier.
I don't anticipate much trouble.
Well, don't forget he's got that rocket full of nerve gas. He can point it at any city in Europe.
Don't worry, Doctor. He won't get the chance. You coming with me?
No, not for the moment. I've got to work out a way of destroying that machine of his. If I can step up the voltage in that coil
Yes, well, er, I'll leave the machine to you, and you can leave Master to me.
Yes, yes, all right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Whilst the Doctor mutters his thoughts, the Keller machine is trying to transport itself out of the collar. Furniture starts flying around the Process Theatre until the power box outside explodes, along with the mains junction box, then the collar breaks into pieces. Finally the nasty thing vanishes.
Two prison officers are checking the area.

Dialogue.Line: Have you looked out here then, Bill?
Yes, Dave, I have.
Oh no!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The familiar sound of the Keller machine starts up as it appears and rips their minds apart.

Dialogue.Line: No!
No, the pain. Please!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They die.
The Doctor is drawing on a circuit diagram when Jo enters. She takes a bowl to Barnham.

Dialogue.Line: Here you are, Barnham. Drink this up while it's hot.
Thank you very much, Miss.
Sergeant Benton will look after you. Won't you, Sergeant?
Right, that's it. That should just about do it, I think.
Wait for me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Jo leaves. The telephone rings.

Dialogue.Line: Sergeant, Acting Governor Benton here.
It's Doctor Summers, Sergeant. I wondered if those medical supplies had arrived yet.
Medical supplies? Hang on, Doctor Summers, I'll check.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benton puts the phone down so he can go through a sheaf of papers. Barnham picks it up.

Dialogue.Line: What do you think you're doing?
Doctor Summers.
You what?
Well, I'd like to talk to Doctor Summers.
Look, you go off and talk to who you like, okay?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Obediently, Barnham leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, Doctor Summers. Yes, they seem to be here all right. They should be on their way over to you now.
Oh my! The thing's escaped again!
How?
Well, it must stored up its energy and blown all the circuits. Let's have a look.
Be careful.
What happened?
Well, it's stronger than ever now. How on earth am I going to stop it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Outside, Barnham comes across the dead prison officers. His head is hurting him.

Dialogue.Line: Will you be able to set the coils up again?
No, that'd never work twice. The thing's too intelligent. In any case, I doubt whether I'd get near enough to it without being killed.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The machine appears on its table. Barnham enters.

Dialogue.Line: What's wrong?
Barnham, get out of here! Get back!
I heard this noise. I was

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The machine goes quiet.

Dialogue.Line: It's stopped.
Machine. I remember this place. Something happened here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As Barnham backs away, the machine starts up again.

Dialogue.Line: Something terrible!
Barnham, come back! Come back! Come back!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor grabs Barnham and uses him as a shield to approach the machine.

Dialogue.Line: No!
Over here!
No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And the machine switches off again.

Dialogue.Line: Don't be frightened by it! Don't be frightened. That's it, that's it. As long as you're here, it won't hurt us. Right, stay there. Stay there. Sit yourself down, that's it.
But I don't understand.
The mind of evil, Jo. I should have realised. That creature feeds on the evil impulses of the brain.
And Barnham hasn't got any.
No, the machine extracted them all. Something in his mind acts as a screen and neutralises it. So long as he's here, we're perfectly safe.
Afternoon, sir.
Afternoon, sir.
Afternoon. How are you, Yates?
Recovering rapidly, sir.
Good. Sit down.
Thank you, sir.
Well, how's it going, Major Cosworth?
Fine, sir. I've just been on to the Ministry of Defence.
And?
Thunderbolt is equipped with an abort mechanism. Once in go condition, it can be blown up at any time.
So, if the Master threatens to launch the missile, we simply blow it up on the ground from here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has opened up the reservoir to reveal a slimy brain-like entity with one staring eye.

Dialogue.Line: (In disgust.) Can't you kill it now, Doctor?
No. No, these creatures are incredibly resilient, Jo. It'd take an atomic explosion or an enormous charge of electricity to destroy that.
So what are we going to do?
Well, I'm going to see. I'm going to see Sergeant Benton. Will you wait here? Will you be all right until I get back?
I'm scared. It's evil.
Yes, I know. I'll be as quick as I possibly can, all right? Now, Jo will look after you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves.

Dialogue.Line: What's your other name?
Now, are you sure you've got all that?
I think so, Doctor. Extra heavy duty cable, arrangements with the National Complex for a maximum power boost. I'll get onto it right away.
Yes, please do. It's all extremely urgent.
It's going to take quite a bit of organising.
Yes, I'm quite sure it is, but neverthe

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The phone rings.

Dialogue.Line: Acting Governor Benton here.
Who?
Stangmoor Prison - Acting Governor Sergeant Benton here.
I see. Er, would the Doctor be there by any chance?
I'll see, sir. Who's calling, please?
Er, just say it's an old friend.
It's for you, Doctor. Say's he's an old friend of yours.
Hello? Yes?
Oh, Doctor, do I gather that the tables have turned somewhat at Stangmoor?
You have gathered correctly.
Barnham?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Summers enters.

Dialogue.Line: Jo, what on earth do you think you're doing? I told Barnham to stay in the medical wing.
He can't leave. We've got to stay here with that thing.
But you'll get yourselves killed.
Doctor Summers, we have got to
Look, Jo! Jo, you know he's not well and that thing's dangerous. I've got to get him back to the medical wing. Now, come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Summers drags Barnham towards the door and the machine starts up.

Dialogue.Line: No! No, you can't!
Argh! My head!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo leads Barnham back to the machine.

Dialogue.Line: Try, Barnham.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: When Barnham sits down again the machine stops.

Dialogue.Line: That thing, it's alive!
Yes, and if Barnham leaves here, that thing will kill all of us.
In spite of what I've said, do you still intend to fire that rocket on London?
I most certainly do!
Well, that would start a world war.
Exactly! And then later when this planet is in ruins, I shall take over.
I see. Aren't you forgetting something?
Am I, Doctor? What?
The dematerialisation circuit from your own Tardis.
You can't leave Earth without that, can you.
Are you offering me a deal?
I am. Hand me back that rocket and I'll return your circuit.
That's very generous of you.
Leave Earth. Stop bothering us. Go somewhere else and be a nuisance elsewhere. Well, what do you say?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master thinks it over.

Dialogue.Line: Well?
Right!

But you will bring that circuit to me here at the hanger. You and you alone. At the first sign of treachery, the first sign of interference from your UNIT friends and I launch the missile immediately.
Sergeant, can you contact the Brigadier for me?
Well, I think so, Doctor. He should be back at mobile HQ by now.
Get onto him at once. Tell him he's got to cancel that attack.
You're quite sure there's nothing I can do?
No, honestly.
All right. Well, I've got a mass of wounded to attend to. I'll be in the medical wing if you need me. Look after him, Jo. And yourself.
Thank you.
Now, you do exactly what Miss Grant tells you, all right? Good lad.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is using the R/T.

Dialogue.Line: But understand that you mustn't go anywhere near him. If he catches sight of a uniform, he'll fire that rocket.
Don't you worry, Doctor. Leave everything to us. I've cancelled the attack and we'll send a dispatch rider to HQ to get your circuit, just in case.
What do you mean, just in case? It's our only chance.
Oh, I don't know, Doctor. There are other ways of dealing with him.
Now look, don't do anything stupid, Brigadier. He means what he says, you know.
Don't you worry, Doctor. Over and out.
Lethbridge Stewart!
The Brigadier knows what he's doing, Doctor.
I sincerely hope so. I'm going back to Miss Grant.
Right, Major Cosworth. I want you to get on to the missile control people. They're to maintain radio link with us and explode the missile when I give the word.
Right away, sir.
Captain Yates, you'll be in charge of the evacuation. I want the area around that hangar completely clear within a ten mile radius.
Right, sir.
Trap One to missile control. Report my signal. Over.
But I don't see why you're so upset. If you give him back the circuit and he hands over the missile
You just don't understand, do you, Jo? Once he gets that circuit back he's free to roam through time and space. We'd never catch him.
Then you'll just have to give in. The Master's got the missile and all we've got is this wretched machine.
Jo, will you stop stating the obvious. What did you say?
I said all we've got is this machine.
Well, that's it. That's the answer. We've got the machine and we've got our friend, Barnham.
I don't understand.
With a little help from you, old chap, we can destroy this machine and the Master at the same time.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master takes a unit out of the control panel then flicks the switches labelled Abort which are hidden under a cover.

Dialogue.Line: Just in case somebody tries to be clever.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The brain has got its cover back on. Barnham goes to pick it up, then recoils.

Dialogue.Line: Don't worry. It can't hurt you.
Come on, old chap, come on.
It's all right.
That's it. All right? Now don't forget. Whatever you do, don't drop it. Now hang on to it tight. Pick it up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barnham picks up the machine.

Dialogue.Line: Come on. That's it. Now, mind how you go. Mind how you go. All right? Not too heavy for you? Good, that's it. Now close the doors after us, will you, Sergeant?
Right, sir.
Now mind his feet.
We tried to explode Thunderbolt on the ground, Doctor, but nothing happened.
What did you expect? The Master may be a scoundrel but he is a scientist. He'll have disconnected the abort mechanism.
There's only one thing for it, Doctor. We'll have to give him back that wretched circuit.
Oh, has it arrived?
Just arrived, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes the caltrop shaped gizmo from the envelope.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, that's it.
Believe me, Doctor, I hate to see the Master escape unpunished as much as you do.
It's where he'll escape to that worries me. What right have we got to let his loose on some other planet?
Unless you've got some better plan, I can see no alternative.
My dear Brigadier, of course I have a better plan.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Black Maria arrives, with Jo, Barnham and the machine in the back. The Master greets the Doctor carrying a gun.

Dialogue.Line: Very strange form of transport, Doctor. I hope you're not going to try anything silly.
No, of course not. No, it's just that Bessie had broken down.
Bessie?
You know, Bessie?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor mimes steering.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, yes!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The back of the van opens.

Dialogue.Line: I think I should warn you that my (mime) is aimed and ready to fire. I just have to press the requisite button.
That's very clever.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor walks over to the missile, turning the Master's back to the van.

Dialogue.Line: My word, you have done well.
Shall we get on with it? Did you bring the circuit with you?
Oh, yes. Here.
May I examine it, please?
How do I know that you won't take the circuit and fire the missile anyway?
I'm afraid you don't. You'll just have to trust me this once.
No, I don't think so.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The machine on the ground by the van.

Dialogue.Line: Now, Doctor!
Hai!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor kicks the gun out of the Master's hand, then he, Jo and Barnham run into the hangar doorway as the Master flails on the ground next to the throbbing machine.

Dialogue.Line: (into R/T) Hello, Brigadier? Jo Grant here. Over.
Hello, Miss Grant. We read you. Over.
Doctor working on missile circuit. Stand by for abort instructions. Over.
Well done, Miss Grant. Greyhound to Windmill three four two. Come in to land. I say again, come in to land.
Wilco.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor finds where the component has been taken out of the panel, and searches for it. The Brigadier and Cosworth wait for news. The Doctor finds the unit and plugs it back in as the helicopter comes in to land. The Doctor resets the controls and runs out.

Dialogue.Line: Right, Jo!
We're on our way. Over and out.
Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They run to the helicopter past the Master still writhing on the ground by the machine. Barnham stops and disrupts the effects so that the Master can get up and into the driving seat of the van. He runs over Barnham and makes his escape. The Doctor and Jo run back to their fallen friend.

Dialogue.Line: He's dead. Come on, Jo. Jo, come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo and the Doctor get in the helicopter and it takes off.

Dialogue.Line: Twenty seconds, missile control.
Ten, nine, eight, seven, six, five, four, three, two, one, abort!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: KaBOOM! goes the missile, the hangar, and presumably the Keller machine and Barnham.
A soldier puts a tray of cups on the desk.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you.
We took Barnham there to help us.
Yes, I know, Jo. I know.
We should never have left him there.
Well, how do you think I feel?
Sorry.
Yes. Here, have some coffee.
Well, at least we're rid of the Keller machine, and the Master.
Yes, we've probably killed off that machine all right, but I'm not so sure about the Master.
Well, even if he wasn't killed, Doctor, he won't get far if you've still got his circuit.
Yes, that's true.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor checks his pockets.

Dialogue.Line: The circuit. I must have lost it in my struggle with him.
Probably destroyed in the explosion.
Yes, but what if it wasn't? Supposing the Master found it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The telephone rings.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, Governor's office?
Put me on to the Doctor, will you?
Yes. It's for you, Doctor.
The Master? Yes?
Ah, Doctor. I was afraid you'd be worried about me, so I thought I'd let you know that I'm alive and well.
I'm extremely sorry to hear that.
I made the safety of my Tardis which, thanks to your generosity, is in perfect working order.
So, we won't be seeing you for quite some time.
Not for quite some time.
But one day, I will destroy this miserable planet and you along with it. Goodbye, Doctor. Oh, by the way, enjoy your exile.
What did he say?
His usual threats.
Never mind, Doctor. You've beaten him.
Have I, Jo? He's got his Tardis back. He's free to come and go where he pleases, while I'm stuck here on Earth (pause) with you, Brigadier!
